wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 4/3/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

What Great Managers Do To Engage Employees

Since 2000, Gallup has reported that less than 1/3 of Americans are engaged in their jobs. Their recent research shows that managers have a big part to play in the employee engagement equation’as much as 70% of variance in employee engagement scores. So what can managers do to enhance the employee experience? Answer: communicate richly, base performance management on clear goals, and focus on strengths over weaknesses.

Why aren’t companies addressing employee engagement?

Traditional approaches to employee engagement consider the HR department the sole owner and driver. While HR is often a powerful facilitator, if employee engagement is only driven by HR, it will fail. The most successful approach is shared ownership and bringing managers and executives into the effort. Why? Dead batteries can’t jump-start others.

Wellness plan incentives drive engagement

The Employee Benefit Research Institute found that when an employee signs on for their company-sponsored wellness plan, is a big indicator of employee health. The study compared employees experienced with wellness programs and those who aren’t. The results reveal that low financial rewards attract the young and healthy, while higher financial rewards may bring in older, less healthy employees who account for a large portion of health care spending.

Managers With High Talent Twice As Likely to Be Engaged

Gallup’s new report, The State of the American Manager, states that just one in 10 people have the unique blend of innate characteristics that Gallup has found to be predictors of management excellence. What’s more is that just 18% of current managers have this high talent’this is a huge opportunity for organizations to reevaluate placement of managers for optimal results.

The next big trend in corporate social investment is emerging’flagship programs

A global sustainability consultancy, Corporate Citizenship, has interviewed some of the world’s leading community managers to understand the status of corporate community and social investment. Research reveals that companies are shifting towards flagship programs, in which a lot of money, volunteers and in-kind donations are focused on a single, significant issue for the organization.
